On the Altra bandwagon, I've added the Superiors to my collection. Out of the box, the shoe was grippy but has seem to lose some of that now. After a hundred or so miles, the lugs are coming off. Altras are hardly the most durable shoes but I still love them.
On the positive sides, the shoe fits and feels great on my foot. The shoe is surprisingly soft for its stack height but it is supple enough that you can feel the ground beneath sole. This shoe will be my go to shoe for racing, intervals, and long runs.

WRITING.TITLE: Tapering and fueling for a 50k
WRITING.TEXT:
Hey all,
I'm about five weeks out from my first 50k ever and I'm a little clueless on the nutrition side of things. What do you guys do race day? There's about 5,000 of climbing and I'm hoping to finish around the 4'30" mark. On my long runs, which are anywhere from 20-22 miles long with 3,000 to 5,000 of vert, I will carry two 20fl oz bottles of water and maybe two gels. That can get me through the run but I'm always pretty wrecked afterwards.
Also, how do you taper for a 50k? I've only raced trail half marathons and I have always done a two week taper. I've been doing about 80mpw with one week over a 100mpw. I'm hoping to hit 100mpw again but with more vert for peak week. Should I do that this week or next week? Race day is June 3.
Thanks!

Something about their trail shoes are just kind of flimsy. I love my superiors and lone peaks but they never last that long. On the other hand, my paradigms and ones have lasted hundreds of miles longer without any major issues

This. Try out different stuff and see what works for you.
Focus on one thing this training cycle, like increasing volume, elevation, or intensity, and see where it takes you. Try different speed workouts, rest days, or long run workouts.

I read Foucault in a couple of my philosophy classes and in a couple of my sociology classes. The philosophy courses did a better job framing his work historically and theoretically. I read Foucault with two different sociology professors, one was more of a Marx-Feminist and the other was an anarcho-capatalist. They both picked works of Foucault that could affirm their theoretical preferences. Foucault, like most prominent thinkers, had a lot to say and it was good to get an idea of his scope as an undergrad. If I were to read him in the future, I would now know where to start and how to read him.

I start to bring an electrolyte drink around the two hour mark, which is about that 15 mile and 2k vert feet mark. After that, my rule is one piece solid food every forty five minutes, a 20oz electrolyte drink every 90 minutes, and possibly extra water if it's hot.
Also, I don't think that elevation directly changes how many calories you burn. You just tend to work harder when climbing

Pretty much. Refer to props 109 and 126 of PI he writes that we resolve philosophical problems by rearranging what is before us, not deducing the answers from propositions, and "Philosophy simply puts everything before us, and neither explains nor deduces anything".
Or here... I'll just link prop. 109 because it's too late for me to be doing any mental work.
"109. It was true to say that our considerations could not be scientific ones. It was not of any possible interest to us to find out empirically 'that, contrary to our preconceived ideas, it is possible to think suchand-such'whatever that may mean. (The conception of thought as a gaseous medium.) And we may not advance any kind of theory. There must not be anything hypothetical in our considerations. We must do away with all explanation, and description alone must take its place. And this description gets its light, that is to say its purpose, from the philosophical problems. These are, of course, not empirical problems; they are solved, rather, by looking into the workings of our language, and that in such a way as to make us recognize those workings: in despite of an urge to misunderstand them. The problems are solved, not by giving new information, but by arranging what we have always known. Philosophy is a battle against the bewitchment of our intelligence by means of language."

This
The biggest difference between the TLP and PI is Wittgenstein's metaphysics. There are some things that Wittgenstein is consistent about throughout his career. In *Logik*, a notebook that he completed when living in a hut in Norway in 1913, he form a conception of philosophy that he goes to his grave with. Here's a quick list:
*Philosophy is purely descriptive. This appears in props. 109 and 126 of PI and all throughout TLP.
*Language gives no pictures of reality. This appears in prop. 6.432 of TLP and props. 420-428 (think private language)
*Philosophy is not a natural science. Prop. 4.11 of TLP, p. 18-19 of the Blue book, and prop. 109 of PI. For Wittgenstein, philosophy is descriptive and science is explanatory.
*"Philosophy consists of logic and metaphysics, the former its basis." Props. 6.53 and 6.111 of TLP and page 35 of the Blue Book.
I do not know how useful this info is but I think the continuity of Wittgenstein's thought is fascinating. I have written a couple of papers on the subject and would write more if I was not so lazy

The density and sugar content of syrup is the same between grades.
Though all grades of pure maple syrup are identical in density and maple sugar content (66.9%), the color of the syrup can and does range from pale golden to dark brown. In fact, maple syrup is graded solely by its color. This difference in color has mostly to do with when the syrup is made. As the spring warms up, the sap coming from the trees becomes darker in color, producing a darker syrup. Corresponding to color, the darker the syrup is, the stronger its flavor. The State of Vermont distinguishes four maple syrup grades. From light to dark they are: Fancy, Grade A Medium Amber, Grade A Dark Amber, and Grade B. It is important to understand that ALL maple syrup is produced by exactly the same process.
[source](http://deepmountainmaple.com/maple-facts-and-fictions)

Grades of maple syrup do not differentiate quality, they differentiate color. Darker colored syrups are B and C. They are produced in the warmer months and have stronger flavor.

WRITING.TITLE: Seeing totals for other sports?
WRITING.TEXT: Hi, does anyone know of a way to see yearly totals for sports other than biking, running, or swimming? I would like to consider skate skiing and backcountry skiing as a part of my annual hourly totals. I could go through every activity and add it up, but that does not seem like fun!
More like rocket appliance

I quit smoking and bought a bike in September of 2014. I rode 68 hours that year. In 2015, I did 160 hours on the bike and ran 100 hours. So far this year, I'm at 212 hours for biking and 140 hours for running.
This summer I consistently did 15 hour weeks with one 4-5 hour ride. I usually ride by feel and rarely do structured workouts on the bike. Usually I like to do 60% moderate/easy, 20% tempo, and 20% threshold or vo2. Running is always 4 days easy, one threshold hill run, and a hard long run.
